Refactoring [1/14]

Refactoring: Changing the structure of code without changing its functionality.

file:links-main

Smells to refactorings

Principles and Patterns [2/14]

Read for next week: http://www.objectmentor.com/resources/articles/Principles_and_Patterns.pdf

Contains the following principles:

Class Design (How to design classes and interfaces):

  1. The Open/Closed Principle: Software entities (classes, modules, etc) should be open for extension, but closed for modification.
  2. The Liskov Substitution Principle: Derived classes must be usable through the base class interface without the need for the user to know the difference.
  3. The Dependency Inversion Principle: Details should depend upon abstractions. Abstractions should not depend upon details. (Make your classes implement interfaces!)
  4. The Interface Segregation Principle: Many client specific interfaces are better than one general purpose interface.

Package Architecture (How to group classes in packages):

  1. The Reuse/Release Equivalency Principle: The granule of reuse is the same as the granule of release. Only components that are released through a tracking system can be effectively reused.
  2. The Common Closure Principle: Classes that change together, belong together.
  3. The Common Reuse Principle: Classes that aren't reused together should not be grouped together.

Package Coupling (How to manage dependencies between packages):

  1. The Acyclic Dependencies Principle: The dependency structure for released components must be a directed acyclic graph. There can be no cycles.
  2. The Stable Dependencies Principle: Dependencies between released categories must run in the direction of stability. The dependee must be more stable than the depender.
  3. The Stable Abstractions Principle: The more stable a class category is, the more it must consist of abstract classes. A completely stable category should consist of nothing but abstract classes.

UML Sequence Diagrams [3/14]

These show the evolution of a system over time. 

         +------------+
         | <<static>> |
         |  SFactory  |
         +------------+
    newS()      |
-------------->+-+  new()   +-----+
               | |--------->| x:S |
               | |          | --- |
               | |          +-----+
               | |  x         | |
   x           | |<- - - - - -+-+
<- - - - - - - +-+             |
                |              |
                |              |
                |              |

Inner Class: Basics [4/14]

An inner-class instance has a link to the outer-class instance that created it. Thus it can reference the fields of the outer object.

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package basics.inner.one;
00002: public class Main {
00003:   private Main() {}
00004:   static public void main (final String[] args) {
00005:     C mc1 = new C(42);  
00006:     C mc2 = new C(36);
00007:     mc1.f();
00008:     mc2.f();
00009:   }
00010: }
00011: 
00012: interface Print { void print(); }
00013: 
00014: class C {
00015:   int cx;
00016:   C(int x) { cx = x; }
00017:   class P implements Print {
00018:     int py = 27;
00019:     public void print() {
00020:       System.out.println(" cx=" + Integer.toString(cx) +
00021:                          " py=" + Integer.toString(py));
00022:     }
00023:   }
00024:   void f() {
00025:     Print p = new P();
00026:     p.print();
00027:   }
00028: }
00029: 
00030:     
00031:

Inner Class: Link Names [5/14]

The outer class link has a funny name:

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package basics.inner.three;
00002: public class Main {
00003:   private Main() {}
00004:   static public void main (final String[] args) {
00005:     C mc1 = new C(42);  
00006:     C mc2 = new C(36);
00007:     mc1.f();
00008:     mc2.f();
00009:   }
00010: }
00011: 
00012: interface Print { void print(); }
00013: 
00014: class C {
00015:   int cx;
00016:   C(int x) { cx = x; }
00017:   class P implements Print {
00018:     int py = 27;
00019:     public void print() {
00020:       System.out.println(" cx=" + Integer.toString(C.this.cx) +
00021:                          " py=" + Integer.toString(this.py));
00022:     }
00023:   }
00024:   void f() {
00025:     Print p = new P();
00026:     p.print();
00027:   }
00028: }
00029:

Inner Class: Anonymous [6/14]

Inner classes that are used once do not need to be named.

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package basics.inner.two;
00002: public class Main {
00003:   private Main() {}
00004:   static public void main (final String[] args) {
00005:     C mc1 = new C(42);  
00006:     C mc2 = new C(36);
00007:     mc1.f();
00008:     mc2.f();
00009:   }
00010: }
00011: 
00012: interface Print { void print(); }
00013: 
00014: class C {
00015:   int cx;
00016:   C(int x) { cx = x; }
00017:   void f() {
00018:     Print p = new Print() {
00019:         int py = 27;
00020:         public void print() {
00021:           System.out.println(" cx=" + Integer.toString(cx) +
00022:                              " py=" + Integer.toString(py));
00023:         }
00024:       };
00025:     p.print();
00026:   }
00027: }
00028:

Inner Class: Extending classes [7/14]

An anonymous inner class may extend a class, rather than implement an interface.

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package basics.inner.four;
00002: public class Main {
00003:   private Main() {}
00004:   static public void main (final String[] args) {
00005:     C mc1 = new C(42);  
00006:     C mc2 = new C(36);
00007:     mc1.f();
00008:     mc2.f();
00009:   }
00010: }
00011: 
00012: abstract class Print {
00013:   int py;
00014:   Print(int y) { py = y; }
00015:   abstract void print();
00016: }
00017: 
00018: class C {
00019:   int cx;
00020:   C(int x) { cx = x; }
00021:   void f() {
00022:     Print p = new Print(27) {
00023:         public void print() {
00024:           System.out.println(" cx=" + Integer.toString(cx) +
00025:                              " py=" + Integer.toString(py));
00026:         }
00027:       };
00028:     p.print();
00029:   }
00030: }
00031:

Factory: Shapes [8/14]

The simplest version exports the concrete class names.

file:Shape.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape1;
00002: import java.awt.Graphics;
00003: public interface Shape {
00004:   void paint(Graphics g);
00005: }
00006:

file:Circle.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape1;
00002: import java.awt.Graphics;
00003: public class Circle implements Shape {
00004:   public void paint(Graphics g) { /* ... */ }
00005:   // ...
00006: }
00007:

file:Square.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape1;
00002: import java.awt.Graphics;
00003: public class Square implements Shape {
00004:   public void paint(Graphics g) { /* ... */ }
00005:   // ...
00006: }
00007:

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape1.main;
00002: import factory.shape1.Shape;
00003: import factory.shape1.Square;
00004: import factory.shape1.Circle;
00005: public class Main {
00006:   public static void main (String[] args) {
00007:     Shape[] a = new Shape[2];
00008:     a[0] = new Circle();
00009:     a[1] = new Square();
00010:   }
00011: }
00012:

Factory: Static Factory Method [9/14]

A factory allows the concrete class names to remain hidden.

file:Shape.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape2;
00002: import java.awt.Graphics;
00003: public interface Shape {
00004:   void paint(Graphics g);
00005: }
00006: class Circle implements Shape {
00007:   public void paint(Graphics g) { /* ... */ }
00008:   // ...
00009: }
00010: class Square implements Shape {
00011:   public void paint(Graphics g) { /* ... */ }
00012:   // ...
00013: }
00014:

file:ShapeFactory.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape2;
00002: public class ShapeFactory {
00003:   private ShapeFactory() {}
00004:   static public Shape newInstance(String selector) {
00005:     if ("Circle".equals(selector)) return new Circle();
00006:     if ("Square".equals(selector)) return new Square();
00007:     throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00008:   }
00009: }
00010:

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape2.main;
00002: import factory.shape2.Shape;
00003: import factory.shape2.ShapeFactory;
00004: public class Main {
00005:   public static void main (String[] args) {
00006:     Shape[] a = new Shape[2];
00007:     a[0] = ShapeFactory.newInstance("Circle");
00008:     a[1] = ShapeFactory.newInstance("Square");
00009:   }
00010: }
00011:

Factory: Benefit [10/14]

Changing names does not affect client code.

file:Shape.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape3;
00002: import java.awt.Graphics;
00003: public interface Shape {
00004:   void paint(Graphics g);
00005: }
00006: class Ellipse implements Shape {
00007:   public void paint(Graphics g) { /* ... */ }
00008:   // ...
00009: }
00010: class Rectangle implements Shape {
00011:   public void paint(Graphics g) { /* ... */ }
00012:   // ...
00013: }
00014:

file:ShapeFactory.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape3;
00002: public class ShapeFactory {
00003:   private ShapeFactory() {}
00004:   static public Shape newInstance(String selector) {
00005:     if ("Ellipse".equals(selector))   return new Ellipse();
00006:     if ("Circle".equals(selector))    return new Ellipse();
00007:     if ("Rectangle".equals(selector)) return new Rectangle();
00008:     if ("Square".equals(selector))    return new Rectangle();
00009:     throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00010:   }
00011: }
00012:

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape3.main;
00002: import factory.shape3.Shape;
00003: import factory.shape3.ShapeFactory;
00004: public class Main {
00005:   public static void main (String[] args) {
00006:     Shape[] a = new Shape[2];
00007:     a[0] = ShapeFactory.newInstance("Circle");
00008:     a[1] = ShapeFactory.newInstance("Square");
00009:   }
00010: }
00011:

Factory: Static Factory Class [11/14]

An alternative is to use multiple factory methods.

file:Shape.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape4;
00002: import java.awt.Graphics;
00003: public interface Shape {
00004:   void paint(Graphics g);
00005: }
00006: class Ellipse implements Shape {
00007:   Ellipse(int radius1, int radius2) { /* ... */ }
00008:   public void paint(Graphics g) { /* ... */ }
00009:   // ...
00010: }
00011: class Rectangle implements Shape {
00012:   Rectangle(int height, int width) { /* ... */ }
00013:   public void paint(Graphics g) { /* ... */ }
00014:   // ...
00015: }
00016:

file:ShapeFactory.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape4;
00002: public class ShapeFactory {
00003:   private ShapeFactory() {}
00004:   static public Shape newEllipse(int radius1, int radius2) {
00005:     return new Ellipse(radius1, radius2);
00006:   }
00007:   static public Shape newCircle(int radius) {
00008:     return new Ellipse(radius, radius);
00009:   }
00010:   static public Shape newRectangle(int height, int width) {
00011:     return new Rectangle(height, width);
00012:   }
00013:   static public Shape newSquare(int height) {
00014:     return new Rectangle(height, height);
00015:   }
00016: }
00017:

file:Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package factory.shape4.main;
00002: import factory.shape4.Shape;
00003: import factory.shape4.ShapeFactory;
00004: public class Main {
00005:   public static void main (String[] args) {
00006:     Shape[] a = new Shape[2];
00007:     a[0] = ShapeFactory.newCircle(1);
00008:     a[1] = ShapeFactory.newSquare(1);
00009:   }
00010: }
00011:

How to test a class in isolation [13/14]

file:hw-03/src/shop/command/CommandHistoryTEST.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package shop.command;
00002: 
00003: import junit.framework.Assert;
00004: import junit.framework.TestCase;
00005: 
00006: public class CommandHistoryTEST extends TestCase {
00007:   public CommandHistoryTEST(String name) {
00008:     super(name);
00009:   }
00010: 
00011:   public void testEmptyExceptions() {
00012:     CommandHistoryObj h = new CommandHistoryObj();
00013:     Assert.assertSame(null, h.topUndoCommand());
00014:     Assert.assertSame(null, h.topRedoCommand());
00015:     Assert.assertFalse(h.getUndo().run());
00016:     Assert.assertFalse(h.getRedo().run());
00017:   }
00018: 
00019:   private void checkStacks(CommandHistoryObj h, UndoableCommand topUndo, UndoableCommand topRedo) {
00020:     Assert.assertSame(topUndo, h.topUndoCommand());
00021:     Assert.assertSame(topRedo, h.topRedoCommand());
00022:   }
00023: 
00024:   public void testThatTopIsSetByAddUndoAndRedo() {
00025:     CommandHistoryObj h = new CommandHistoryObj();
00026: 
00027:     class CmdSuccess implements UndoableCommand {
00028:       public boolean run() { return true; }
00029:       public void undo() { }
00030:       public void redo() { }
00031:     }
00032: 
00033:     UndoableCommand x1 = new CmdSuccess();
00034:     UndoableCommand x2 = new CmdSuccess();
00035:     UndoableCommand x3 = new CmdSuccess();
00036: 
00037:     h.add(x1);          checkStacks(h, x1,   null);
00038:     h.getUndo().run();  checkStacks(h, null, x1);
00039:     h.getRedo().run();  checkStacks(h, x1,   null);
00040: 
00041:     h.add(x2);          checkStacks(h, x2,   null);
00042:     h.getUndo().run();  checkStacks(h, x1,   x2);
00043:     h.getUndo().run();  checkStacks(h, null, x1);
00044:     h.getRedo().run();  checkStacks(h, x1,   x2);
00045:     h.getRedo().run();  checkStacks(h, x2,   null);
00046: 
00047:     h.getUndo().run();  checkStacks(h, x1,   x2);
00048:     h.add(x3);          checkStacks(h, x3,   null);
00049:     h.getUndo().run();  checkStacks(h, x1,   x3);
00050:     h.getUndo().run();  checkStacks(h, null, x1);
00051:     h.getRedo().run();  checkStacks(h, x1,   x3);
00052:     h.getRedo().run();  checkStacks(h, x3,   null);
00053: 
00054:     h = new CommandHistoryObj();
00055:     h.add(x1);          checkStacks(h, x1,   null);  
00056:     h.add(x2);          checkStacks(h, x2,   null);
00057:     h.getUndo().run();  checkStacks(h, x1,   x2);  
00058:     h.getRedo().run();  checkStacks(h, x2,   null);  
00059:     h.add(x3);          checkStacks(h, x3,   null);  
00060:     h.getUndo().run();  checkStacks(h, x2,   x3);
00061:     h.getUndo().run();  checkStacks(h, x1,   x2);
00062:   }
00063: 
00064:   // these must be fields so that they can be changed by the instances
00065:   // of the inner class TestThatMethodsArePerformed.
00066:   private boolean _didRun;
00067:   private boolean _didUndo;
00068:   private boolean _didRedo;
00069: 
00070:   public void testThatMethodsArePerformed() {
00071:     CommandHistoryObj h = new CommandHistoryObj();
00072: 
00073:     class MockCommand implements UndoableCommand {
00074:       // Using "CommandHistoryTEST.this" to make references to
00075:       // outer class instance explicit
00076:       public boolean run() {
00077:         CommandHistoryTEST.this._didRun = true;
00078:         return true;
00079:       }
00080:       public void undo() {
00081:         CommandHistoryTEST.this._didUndo = true;
00082:       }
00083:       public void redo() {
00084:         CommandHistoryTEST.this._didRedo = true;
00085:       }
00086:     }
00087: 
00088:     UndoableCommand x = new MockCommand();
00089: 
00090:     _didRun = _didUndo = _didRedo = false;
00091:     h.add(x);
00092:     Assert.assertTrue(!_didRun && !_didUndo && !_didRedo);
00093: 
00094:     _didRun = _didUndo = _didRedo = false;
00095:     h.getUndo().run();
00096:     Assert.assertTrue(!_didRun && _didUndo && !_didRedo);
00097: 
00098:     _didRun = _didUndo = _didRedo = false;
00099:     h.getRedo().run();
00100:     Assert.assertTrue(!_didRun && !_didUndo && _didRedo);
00101:   }
00102: }
00103:
